title: Question 66

children: A 38-year-old man is evaluated for a 4-day history of bilateral eye redness, watery discharge, and pruritus as well as rhinitis and sneezing. He has no other symptoms. He experiences similar symptoms around the same time each year. He does not wear contact lenses. Medical history is otherwise unremarkable, and he takes no medications.
On physical examination, there is swelling and erythema of the conjunctiva bilaterally associated with clear, watery discharge. The remainder of the examination is normal.
Which of the following is the most appropriate topical treatment?
Perennial allergic conjunctivitis presents with bilateral eye redness, pruritus, and watery discharge.
Topical antihistamines with mast cell–stabilizing effects are first-line therapies for uncomplicated allergic conjunctivitis.
An antihistamine with mast cell–stabilizing properties is the most appropriate topical treatment (
Option B

). This patient presents with bilateral eye redness, pruritus, and watery discharge, which are characteristic of perennial allergic conjunctivitis. Allergic conjunctivitis is due to IgE-mediated mast cell degranulation, with the resultant release of histamine and other inflammatory mediators. In addition to basic eye care, including cold compresses, and avoiding eye rubbing and known allergens, topical pharmacotherapy is indicated for this patient given the degree of his symptoms. Topical agents in this category include olopatadine, alcaftadine, bepotastine, azelastine hydrochloride, cetirizine, epinastine, ketotifen fumarate, and emedastine. Generic ketotifen fumarate does not require a prescription. Although the full effect of these agents may take days, some effect is seen immediately. An advantage of this class of drugs is that it is administered only once or twice daily, depending on the specific formulation. The most common side effect is burning and stinging with application, which may be mitigated by using refrigerated agents.
Topical antibiotics (
Option A

), such as trimethoprim-polymyxin B, have no role in the treatment of uncomplicated allergic conjunctivitis. This class of drug is effective for treating acute bacterial conjunctivitis in patients who do not wear contact lenses. Factors favoring bacterial conjunctivitis include glued eyes in the morning, redness completely obscuring the tarsal vessels, purulent discharge, and a red eye observed at 20 feet. Absence of a purulent discharge makes bacterial conjunctivitis very unlikely.
Topical glucocorticoids (
Option C

), such as prednisolone, are effective for allergic conjunctivitis but are associated with serious potential side effects, including vision loss; glaucoma; corneal damage; and, with prolonged use, cataracts. They should be reserved for patients who have refractory symptoms and administered only under close supervision of an ophthalmologist for short periods. They would therefore be inappropriate to use in this patient.
A mast cell–stabilizing agent (
Option D

), such as cromolyn, is effective therapy for allergic conjunctivitis. However, it needs to be used for up to 14 days before complete efficacy is reached and requires administration four times daily, which may decrease adherence. Therefore, use is reserved for those patients in whom other therapies have failed.
Topical NSAIDs (
Option E

) function by blocking the breakdown of thromboxane. Although topical NSAIDs have some efficacy in the treatment of allergic conjunctivitis compared with placebo, they are less effective than antihistamines and are not a first-line treatment.

references: Bielory L, Delgado L, Katelaris CH, et al. ICON: diagnosis and management of allergic conjunctivitis. Ann Allergy Asthma Immunol. 2020;124:118-34.
